Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research (Arabidopsis 2010): Ecological Genomics of Adaptation to the Environment
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research investigates the ecological and genetic mechanisms that allow the plant Arabidopsis thaliana to adapt (grow, survive and reproduce) to different natural environments. Using wild populations from the extremes of a natural gradient in temperature and length of daylight, the investigators will identify the traits and genes that govern plant performance in nature. Traits of particular interest include flowering time, freezing and drought tolerance, and the capacity of plants to photosynthesize (make energy from sunlight) under conditions of physiological stress. The investigators will identify the genes that contribute to adaptation in nature and the magnitude of the effect of individual genes. A major goal of this work is to investigate the importance of genes that have positive effects in one environment but negative effects in other environments. Such genes are poorly understood but are thought to play a key role in adaptation.

The study will provide a deeper understanding of the mechanisms that allow plants to cope with different environments and has the potential to provide genetic tools for producing new varieties of plants/crops. In addition, the study system is well suited to investigate the possible consequences of global climate change and the potential of plants to adapt to rapidly changing conditions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Gardeners, landscapers and farmers have long recognized that most plants grow best in particular climates. For example, plants that do well in cold environments often grow poorly in warm environments, and vice versa.  How plants adapt to their local environments and how local adaptation influences the ability of plants to grow elsewhere are questions that have intrigued plant scientists for centuries. Are populations adapted to their local environments? If so, what are the traits and genes that contribute to adaptation? Does adaptation to one environment reduce performance in other environments? To answer these questions, a research team from Michigan State University (Doug Schemske, Mike Thomashow) working in collaboration with Professor Jon Ågren from Uppsala University (Sweden) have investigated adaptation in the Mouse-eared cress, the first plant to have its full genetic makeup catalogued.

They identified two populations for study, one in Sweden near the northern limit of the native range and one in Italy, near the southern range limit. In the first phase of their research, they grew plants from seed originally collected at each site in gardens established at each site. This experimental design is termed a "reciprocal transplant," and is used to determine if plants are adapted to their local conditions. Indeed, they found that Swedish plants performed best in Sweden, while Italian plants performed best in Italy--strong evidence for local adaptation.

Next, they conducted crosses between the two populations, grew the offspring at both sites for multiple years, and used genetic techniques to identify regions of the genome (the collection of all genes in an organism) that contribute to plant growth, survival and reproduction. Over the three years of study, the researchers grew 43,964 plants, and counted 565,070 fruits. They found 15 genomic regions that controlled plant performance. This is far fewer than would be expected by the widely accepted model of adaptation which predicts that adaptation is caused by a nearly infinite number of genes, each with tiny effects on performance. They also found that one third of the genomic regions that control adaptation are involved in a "tradeoff", meaning that the local versions of genes in these regions improve performance in their home sites. In Sweden, a surprising number of the local genomic regions were found to reduce performance. This is strong evidence that a lack of genetic variation in Sweden limits adaptive potential.

Finally, through extensive observations in the natural populations and studies in specialized growth chambers that simulated Italian and Swedish environments, the researchers identified two factors responsible for local adaptation--flowering time in Italy, and freezing tolerance in Sweden. In Italy, early flowering (February-April) is favored to avoid the hot, dry summers, while in Sweden, plants must be cold tolerant to survive the long, cold winters (four months).

One of the most intriguing results is that the genetic information encoded by a major gene known to control freezing tolerance differs between Swedish and Italian populations. In Sweden, the gene is fully functional, and allows plants to persist at sub-freezing temperatures. In contrast, the Italian version of this gene is non-functional, such that plants with the Italian gene are severely damaged, and often killed, by freezing temperatures. Field experiments demonstrated that the Swedish gene is favored in Sweden, while the Italian gene is favored in Italy. This is a striking example of a genetic tradeoff, in that the local version of each gene is favored. Why would the high freezing tolerance caused by the Swedish version of the gene be disfavored in Italy? The most likely explanation is that freezing tolerance is costly, and that the benefits exceed the costs only in cold environments like Sweden.&...
